intro: Chavica siriboa, commonly known as the Indian chervil, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its delicate, fern-like leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30-60 cm and thrives in well-drained soil with full sun exposure. Its seeds are used in traditional medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. Chavica siriboa is also valued in ornamental gardening for its attractive foliage and subtle floral display.
